abstract.t: The development of DNS over HTTPS (DoH), defined in RFC8484, introduces a major change to the way in which devices and applications are able to use the Domain Name System. DoH traffic uses HTTP over a TLS session. DoH clients and servers can use HTTP primitives to request and supply DNS data instead of conventional DNS queries and responses using port 53. This presents a number of challenges, including new risks and security concerns, for those operating and running IP-based networks.
The objective of this document is to describe these challenges and provide advice on how to minimise their impact.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document is focussed on DoH deployment issues. Several of these issues also occur in other DNS transports. However, the authors feel that, at this time, consideration of other transports should be made in other documents and in the appropriate working groups.

At present, most traditional DNS traffic is not encrypted. This can pose a privacy challenge for Internet users, because their access to named network resources can potentially be tracked through their DNS queries. In principle, any network element along the path between the user and resolver could observe this unencrypted traffic. DoH eliminates this problem by using TLS to encrypt the queries and responses that are made. These use HTTP rather than the conventional DNS protocol. Furthermore DoH traffic can be intermingled with other HTTPS traffic, making it difficult for an eavesdropper to monitor DNS traffic or even be aware that it is taking place.

A new model of DNS usage is created with DoH. A DoH server takes on the role of the recursive resolving server in conventional DNS. DoH clients send DNS queries to DoH servers over DoH instead of plaintext DNS queries to a conventional recursive resolving server. This DoH server is likely to be operated and controlled by a third party - i.e. not whoever operates and controls the existing recursive resolver DNS servers in some network. That in turn disrupts the long standing and well understood trust relationships in traditional DNS.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: DoH Server: A server supporting the DNS over HTTPS is called a "DoH server" to differentiate it from a "DNS server" (one that only provides DNS service over one or more of the other transport protocols standardised for DNS). Similarly, a client that supports the DNS over HTTPS is called a "DoH client". The DoH server is a recursive resolver, handling DNS queries from end users/devices, rather than an authoritative DNS server.
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Contrasting DoH and Conventional DNS
section.t: With conventional DNS today, using UDP or TCP port 53, most users are assigned the IP addresses of several recursive resolvers via DHCP or similar network bootstrapping mechanism. These are usually the IP addresses of recursive resolvers that are administered by the network operator. Users sometimes also change to third-party recursive resolvers. In some cases, they may even operate their own local resolver.

RFC 8484 defines the protocol for DNS over HTTPS (DoH). When DoH is used, client and server DNS traffic is encrypted using a TLS channel, typically to port 443. DoH clients will have little need for conventional DNS apart from an initial bootstrap query to find the IP addresses of a suitable DoH server. This will mean the bulk of their DNS resolver traffic would bypass an operator's DNS resolver infrastructure because that traffic will make use of the resolver service provided by the DoH server.
DoH displaces the traditional DNS client-server model of clients making queries and waiting for a reply from a server.

section.title: DoH Impact on Existing DNS Behaviour
DNS servers using Access Control Lists
section.t: When a DoH server performs the role of a recursive resolving DNS server, it queries other DNS or DoH servers to resolve the queries received from DoH clients. These outbound queries will use a source IP address of the DoH server, not the originating client. This may sometimes cause operational or security problems, for instance when the DoH server queries another DoH or DNS server that uses access control lists based on source IP address. In this case, the ACL applies to the DoH server and not the original DoH client. That can mean the DoH client eventually gets a different response than if it made the query itself. In particular, this may be a problem for IXFR or AXFR queries because authoritative DNS servers commonly use ACLs to restrict these queries.

This problem becomes more acute for dynamic updates RFC 2137. If an ACL-based on source IP address is used to accept or reject these requests, it will be the address of the DoH server rather than the DoH client which determines the outcome. However Transaction Signatures (TSIG) RFC2845 are more commonly used for authenticating dynamic update requests. It is therefore essential for DoH servers to ensure that TSIG resource records received from DoH clients are included in outgoing requests. DoH servers MUST ensure TSIG resource records included in any requests received from DoH clients are included whenever the DoH server has to contact another DoH or DNS server to satisfy that request. Similarly, DoH servers MUST return to DoH clients any TSIG resource records that are received from DNS or DoH servers.

section.title: Split DNS
section.t: Split DNS configurations RFC8499 are widely used, particularly in enterprise networks. These have an internal name space which is not visible to the public Internet. Resolving DNS servers in such networks are configured to only provide answers for this name internal space to requests from clients on the enterprise network. Applications and devices making DoH requests on networks which use split DNS will not be able to access these internal names unless their requests are sent to a suitably configured DoH server. This probably means that networks using split DNS SHOULD provide DoH servers which are able to provide answers for the internal name space.

Use of third-party DoH servers is not recommended in networks which have split DNS. These servers are unlikely to know about the configuration of the local network and will therefore be unable to resolve or otherwise properly handle requests for the internal name space. This also presents security and privacy risks. Requests from DoH clients for internal names will leak, disclosing sensitive information to an external DoH server which is operated and controlled by a third party. DoH clients on networks using split DNS SHOULD query DoH servers which have been configured for that network's internal name space.

section.title: Secure DNS (DNSSEC)
section.t: RFC 8484 explains that interactions between a DoH server and client benefit from the transport security provided by HTTPS and that DoH does not provide message integrity. Put simply, although a DoH client can be sure it received exactly the data sent by a DoH server, it does not know if that server is telling the truth. That can only be verified by DNSSEC validation, assuming that the DNS data are signed. Therefore a security-conscious DoH client SHOULD support DNSSEC and perform DNSSEC validation by itself. In some circumstances, a DoH client MAY trust a DoH server to validate signed responses on their behalf but MUST take full account of the conseqences of doing so.

section.title: Browser Caches
section.t: A web browser maintains a cache of recent DNS data. Responses from DoH servers will affect the contents of that cache. This presents a security risk because it provides a way for DoH servers to arbitrarily manipulate the content of a browser's cache that would not be possible with conventional DNS.

DoH servers SHOULD NOT send DoH data (i.e. application/dns-message elements) unrelated to the request made by a DoH Client. Similarly, a web server SHOULD NOT send DoH data that does not correspond to any of the URIs in the HTML which is returned. i.e. If all the URIs on some web page are for foo.example.com, the web server SHOULD NOT send application/dns-message elements for bar.example.com or example.net. DoH clients SHOULD ignore such unrelated DoH data sent by a DoH or web server. DoH clients MUST NOT cache such data.
Browser caches MUST respect the TTL in the response DNS RRSet.

section.title: Recommendations
section.t: DoH servers MUST NOT create an alternate root.
The responses received over DoH MUST be available in the traditional DNS.
The DoH server MAY make choices about which RRs to return if it knows more about the network topology.
The DoH server MAY push useful additional RRs if it knows the client is likely to need them soon. Again, they MUST be available in the traditional DNS.
DoH servers MUST support DNSSEC.
DoH clients SHOULD support DNSSEC.
